title: Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions:
I applied to a supervisory position at my local IRC office. I got an email from someone in a different state asking if I had time to do an interview, and if so, let them know when and also be sure to take into account that they are in another time zone. Kind of weird that they did not do that themselves and offer me a few options, but ok. We agreed on a day and time, so I was surprised when they called me a day earlier than what we had discussed. They called again on the scheduled day and started off the interview by telling me what the pay rate would be and if that was acceptable. I said unfortunately it would not work for me, since this was a supervisor position & would also carry a caseload. She then offered $1-2 more and said "this is a nonprofit." When I again declined and then stated it would be a +$15k pay cut from my current role at another nonprofit, that was the end of the interview. I understand that the IRC is not a for profit company, but the amount offered was insulting for a position that required managing a team and a caseload. It is horrifying to think what case managers, admin, and support staff are being paid- there is no way it is a liveable wage.

Overall, it felt very disorganized and didn't make much sense that someone on the other side of the country was interviewing for a position with such a heavy focus on community outreach and working with local providers when that person clearly didn't know anything about our community. It would have also saved me (and likely others) a lot of time if IRC would just be transparent and list the pay on the job description. I would not have applied.

Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Los Angeles, CA) in May 2022
Interview Descriptions:
Red Flag 1 - Spelling errors in the job posting 

Red Flag 2 - No salary listed 

1st Interview - With the HR recruiter. It went very well, she was nice and created a warm environment.

They fired questions at me with no option for conversation. I was told I would have time to ask questions at the end, but the  Senior TA repeatedly took over the interview by asking additional questions after they agreed to turn the remaining time over to me. 

This indicated they had no interest in my perspective, or alignment concerns as an applicant or a potential colleague. The vibe was condescending; and seriously not appreciated. I was a bit shocked considering they design workforce development programs, but on reflection, it makes sense. This division of IRC is OLD world Economic Dev wherein workers are meant to feel grateful for any old job that comes along, no matter the environment or benefits. 

Red Flag 4 - I had 2minutes to ask questions. If an applicant can be asked this during an interview, they should expect the same. My question clearly rubbed them the wrong way, as the Senior TA looked visibly displeased. 

If you can't in good faith reflect on the areas your team needs to improve, that indicates a serious lack of self awareness or conscious ignorance. 

Red Flag 5 - No POC on the Workforce team 

Final Red Flag - The job is listed as a PO but the duties are clearly that of a Director. The Director is always traveling, so it's clear that the POs are doing this work in her stead.  This isn't an issue if the job is getting 90K+, but their budget is 70-80K.

title: Regional Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (New York, NY)
Interview Descriptions:
I completed an HR screening interview, an interview with the hiring manager, a 3 hour written assessment and an additional interview with the head of the department.  I was also requested to provide 4-5 references. 

After spending an immense amount of time going through this process over the course of two months, I was initially told I was the final candidate and that an offer would be sent shortly.  However, at the last minute I was contacted by the recruiter to say that they would no longer be able to accommodate me working remotely and the position had to be based in NY.  During each of the THREE interviews I was assured that working remotely (from another state) would be totally fine. I was told this was a shift made by senior leadership. I'm not sure how HR or the hiring manager didn't know about this shift beforehand. Luckily I had not given notice to my current job, otherwise I would have been in real trouble. This was my dream job, I was so excited to work with both the hiring manager and director. I found it really disappointing that neither the hiring manager or director reached out to me to apologize about stringing me along through this process out of respect for my time. I only received a curt email from the recruiter. It was a difficult experience that  has affected my mental health.

I have worked for the IRC in the past and I have tremendous respect and admiration for the organization. However, the treatment I received during this interview process was incredibly disappointing. I would also caution those considering working for the organization that they are sorely behind in their DEI practices. While they do hire diverse candidates for the lower levels of management, representation at the leadership at the HQ level is lacking.  There are incredibly limited opportunities for growth which is  why I left the organization initially, and contributes to high turnover. I'm also not sure how I feel about the organization being based in one of the most expensive cities in the country... how does that help to recruit diverse talent? As a person of color (and first generation immigrant) myself, I am already struggling to make ends meet where I live currently. Moving to NY would not be an option for me or my family. Furthermore, consider the immense overhead costs incurred by having a NY based HQ office. The org is extremely hierarchical and has not been receptive to feedback in my experience. Again, it pains me to say this, because I really have so much respect for this organization's mission. I hope that they review their hiring and DEI practices soon and are more transparent about changes they make and the breakdown of diversity at all levels of the organization.
Interview Questions: Standard interview questions about work style, some scenario based questions.

Interview Descriptions: Received a video call from the east coast but we didn't use video; the position was very different than I thought it would be as I wouldn't necessarily be working with refugees in the position
Interview Questions: The pay was non-negotiable and the job was temporary. A second interview wasn't guaranteed or anything but they wanted to know if moving forward was a possibility for me.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: ~30 min interview with typical questions. Towards the end I was given hypothetical situations specific to the position I applied for. I was asked how I would address them as an intern.
Interview Questions: Why  do you want to work at the IRC?

title: Economic Development Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: Very positive, was a team interview so I answered several questions about my background and skills. Staff seemed to care quite a bit, very encouraging. Would review your own background and think a bit about why you want to intern at the IRC.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work at the IRC?

title: Graphic Design Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Salt Lake City, UT) in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: There were two interview rounds, first with a general hiring manager and second with four members of the team I was to be working with. Both rounds were over Zoom call.
Interview Questions: Q: How would you communicate with someone (a client in this case) who speaks very little English?

title: Case Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: Quick and had a quick turn around time. They asked me good questions and I asked them questions back. First interview was 15 minutes. I hope they hired someone good.
Interview Questions: When can you start work?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: The interviewer was very nice, very attentive, and very patient. IRC provides onboarding training and gives interns time to learn how to use the organization's work systems. The interviewer explained the responsibilities of the position for me in great detail, and there were application scenario questions in the interview to examine whether the candidate was a good match for the position.
Interview Questions: What's one of the challenges you've had in your previous internship?

title: Resettlement Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: Simple questions about previous work experience, work with people, interpreting abilities; not a lot of flexibility in funding transportation costs— initial video interview required for screening and second interview for behavioral questions and deeper look at work experience
Interview Questions: Why do you want to intern at the IRC?

title: Finance Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Nairobi) in Feb 2022
Interview Descriptions:
Fast, efficient, and positive. I did 3 stages of interviews online in a span of 2 weeks.
I loved that about the experience because you are not left wondering how you did for long.
Interview Questions: Why I'm the best fit for the job.

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (New York, NY)
Interview Descriptions: The whole process was very smooth and professional. There was an initial call and a final interview and few steps after that. My advice would be to just be yourself
Interview Questions: So tell me about yourself.

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions:
Initial interview with many behavioral questions. Describe a time when.....
Second interview with hiring manager a range of question types. more of a 'get to know you' emphasis with ample opportunity to ask questions.
Interview Questions:
5 behavioral Qs:
1.	Time when I modified communication style to meet needs of a colleague 
2.	Something about cross-cultural sensitivity
3.	Time when I received critical feedback and how I responded, what I did
4.	How I have led/participated/taken action to promote/uphold Safeguarding culture

title: Health Coach Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: I applied for the job online and was contacted within two weeks. I got a phone call interview and then an in person meeting with the hiring manager. The process took about a month or less.
Interview Questions: How have you shown support for LGBTQ?

title: Program Officer Interview
Application Type: The process took 6 months. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: From when I first heard from the recruiter to when I was hired, over six months passed. I had multiple interviews and there was no real urgency. All positions are tied to grant funding, so be sure you understand which grant is paying the salary and the expectation of whether it will continue beyond one or two years
Interview Questions: Describe a time when you had to make a difficult decision at work.

title: Student Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Berlin)
Interview Descriptions: Vorstellung, Fragen zu Erfahrung, Englisch und Deutsch, mehrere Personen, die Fragen zu verschiedenen Themen stellen. Bezogen auf Stellenausschreibung. Sehr angenehm, alle freundlich. Man kann auch selbst viel fragen. Fragen nach Arbeitsweisen, failings, Erfolgen etc.
Interview Questions: Wie würdest du vorgehen, wenn...

title: Research Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (London, England) in Dec 2021
Interview Descriptions: One week advance notice; standard questions plus some creative ones; friendly process;  waited one week wait for notification; feedback provided but minimum information given; job was readvertised and advised in feedback I did not have enough experience - suggests shortlisting process was poor.
Interview Questions:
What are the three skills you would look for in this role if you were hiring? 

Follow up - which of these skills are you least qualified in?

title: Senior Auditor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: The interview is a mixture of both technical and situational questions. The HR professionals are friendly and willing to offer as much information to aid in preparation of the interview process
Interview Questions: Walk me through the internal audit process

title: Business Analyst Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: The first part was a timed written test that included editing a powerpoint; next was an interview with HR (over the phone); the final step was an interview with the team (four interviewers joining over video call)
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in IRC?

title: Senior Communications Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: Process was very quick and was in three stages: (1) interview with the HR focal point, (2) interview with the hiring manager, (3) technical test which included developing a communications strategy. The technical test was what you would expect based on the job description, and resembled very closely the actual work done on the job when I finally started the role.
Interview Questions: How do you manage a project with multiple stakeholders and make sure it is completed on time.

title: Grant Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: After 2 weeks, I was invited to a 2h written test that was fairly straightfoward. About a week after, I had the interview. The panel was very friendly, the interview lasted about 40 mins, with some harder questions thrown in with more standard ones.
Interview Questions:
Why do you want to work here?
How do you deal with stress?
What part of the job would you find most challenging?
How do you maintain good working relations with colleagues?

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: Average interview with many different situational questions. Difficult to be an unpaid intern and expect them to drive people around. Would need to be compensated some how. They also don’t do a good job of letting you know you didn’t get the position.
Interview Questions: Situational questions. Many what would you dos

title: Content Development Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee in Oct 2021
Interview Descriptions: I was called for an initial 15-30 minute phone screening, then was called for a 1-hour full panel interview with three members from different departments.  The main interviewer (who would be the supervisor of the position I was applying for) was incredibly friendly and kind. It started with typical questions regarding why I wanted to work for IRC, how my experience ties into this role, how I would tackle certain tasks, etc.
Interview Questions:
Why do you want to work for IRC? 
What are some additional pieces of content that I would put together for the given audience?
What platforms would I use to reach the audience?

title: Economic Empowerment Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: It was a standard structure for interview (personal connection to the cause, skillsets, what if scenarios and conversation afterwards. I was interviewed by friendly interviewers and gave insight into the position.
Interview Questions: Personal connection to refugee/asylee advocacy, skillset, and some what-if scenarios.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Los Angeles, CA)
Interview Descriptions: It was a pretty standard interview. (Remote due to the COVID 19 pandemic). The interviewer was very friendly and willing to support my career interests with the various placement opportunities.
Interview Questions: Why did you choose to apply to ERC?

title: Finance Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Nairobi) in Sept 2021
Interview Descriptions:
Applying  online, 
First interview was test focused mainly on auditing , tax and accounting
Second interview was in person  technical question were the most and a few personality questions.

Read job description in detail
Interview Questions:
Auditing process
Grants process
Tell me about yourself

title: Caseworker Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee in Sept 2021
Interview Descriptions: Long and so unnecessary. So many interviews, which I thought was not necessary for the type of job and pay. It would have been better to make the interview at least 1 and ask relevant questions not multiple interviews yet repeating the questions.
Interview Questions: About yourself and how much you know about the refugee resettlement process

title: Officer Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: I submitted application. And got an email to proceed to the next stage which was virtual interview using zoom. But I withdrew my application as I got another opportunity at the other organization.
Interview Questions: Why did you apply to this position?

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Denver, CO) in Aug 2021
Interview Descriptions: I would like to make sure to state that not every experience will be like mine, it could just be one bad employee in a sea of good ones. I did a virtual interview, and the interviewer could of obviously cared less about talking to me. Even though I got offered a roll (so I clearly didn’t do bad) the whole time she stared at me blank faced. She did not introduce herself and she was late to the call. The interview was so uncomfortable I decided right after I would not accept the position if offered.
Interview Questions: How do you stay up to date with current events.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: One initial, virtual interview with one person which lasted about 30 minutes. The questions were about my background and what I was hoping to get out of the internship (what my research focus is). I heard back about a week after the interview.
Interview Questions: What humanitarian crisis do you think is underreported in the news?

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: Many steps to the interview process, as is custom with larger companies. You will need 5 references compared to the customary 2-3 references most postings ask for. The process also includes a timed assignment, so as long as you use your time carefully, you should be fine.
Interview Questions: I was asked very standard interview questions, nothing quite stood out.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: Spoke on the phone with people from two different departments. Very friendly and passionate people; open about job responsibilities and willing to incorporate personal goals and preferences into determining tasks.
Interview Questions: Why IRC? What do you see yourself doing in five years?

title: Social Worker Supervisor Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: I spoke first with the recruiter and then had my first virtual interview. I was then called a week later and we set up a secondary interview. Afterward, I never heard back. They completely ghosted me. I understand that ghosting in the interview process happens, but I was very far in the interview process and it would have been nice to have them at least extend the courtesy of a generic email.
Interview Questions: What are you looking for in a supervisor?

title: Employment Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Silver Spring, MD)
Interview Descriptions: The interview was professional and fair. I had 3 interviews. The 1st one with the recruiter, 2nd with the program manager, and the last one with the director. the hiring process took almost one month.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to leave your current job?

title: M&E Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions:
2 major points of feedback: 

2 interviews, an assignment, and references are excessive for an unpaid internship. 

Unpaid internships are outdated and perpetuate inequity within the development and NGO world. IRC should really reconsider this program.
Interview Questions: Typical questions about past experience, why the IRC, and how the role would help my career goals.

title: Bi Developer and Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: I had 3 interviews. First with HR she was nice and asked easy questions. I was then sent a test which I found easy and was able to complete it within allocated time. My last interview was with the hiring manager. After that I got the usual automated emails being told I was not succesful.
Interview Questions: What kind of boss would you want to work under?

title: Monitoring and Evaluation Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Sokoto, Sokoto)
Interview Descriptions: The test was very impossible, i was contacted for the interview but couldn't make it to mubi because of the Covid 19 test. i was then sent a difficult test to submit in one hour thirty MINs.
Interview Questions: Interprete an ERD graph showing baseline, midline and endline values

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions:
Fairly straightforward phone interview. It was quick; lasted only about 20 minutes. Standard scenario questions. 

The interviewer did not ask many questions about my personal or professional background. The questions were fairly vague.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time when you had a disagreement with a colleague.

title: Public Policy Internship Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: Had two rounds of interviews, wasn't offered the job. Both conversations ran around 30 minutes and interviewers were folks working in the office and would have been part of the team I was working on.
Interview Questions: What is your experience in immigrant rights advocacy?

title: Fundraising copywriter Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: The whole process lasted a month. About a week after applying, I was invited to an interview with HR.  Another week after the HR meeting, I was asked to complete a writing exercise. Five days after that, I was invited to a second interview with hiring manager. I never heard back after completing the second interview.
Interview Questions: How have you advanced gender equity in your work?

title: Safety and Wellness Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: Two rounds of interviews. The first interview was with HR and the second was with my potential supervisor. I was offered the job during my second round. Typical behavioral and fit questions, brief interview, only maybe 30 mins each.
Interview Questions: What about the mission of the International Rescue Committee appealed to you?

title: Asylum Office Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (New York, NY) in May 2021
Interview Descriptions: Very good I thought that it was an excellent interview I enjoyed it very much I'm really just writing this to continue using glass door so yeah that's why I'm writing this
Interview Questions: What do you most enjoy about working in the non-profit sphere

title: Assistant Financial Controller Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: Never made it in the door. So bummed that my resume for a job I was highly qualified for didn't even have a phone call. I would have at least liked a point of contact.
Interview Questions: Did not ask my experience. I would have liked more consideration.

title: Systems Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (New York, NY)
Interview Descriptions:
First was the Pre screening interview with hiring manager. To test proficiency in Ms Office tools, 
Followed by a HR interview with the recruiter, 
Then the technical interview with the hiring manager
Interview Questions: What technical skills do you possess for this role?

title: Grants Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: I applied for the position. IRC got in touch within a week. The period between application submission and first interview was quite fast. I liked that.  Even though I did not proceed beyond the first round, IRC was clear on the criteria selection for next steps, which I liked as well.
Interview Questions: Tell us about yourself and why do you want to join IRC

title: Assistant Finance Officer (Acting) Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Tripoli) in Apr 2021
Interview Descriptions: I applied for the job in early march and got an email on early april with confirmation details for an interview over skype that was scheduled for the nest day the next day came and they called and the questions were fairly easy and general
Interview Questions: How did you know about this position?

title: Fundraising Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee in Apr 2021
Interview Descriptions: Very friendly team all around, warm and responsive recruiter. First interview with the recruiter, 2nd with the hiring manager, 3rd with other members of the team. They all felt very conversational and the questions made sense in relation to the position. Nothing too difficult. The whole process took a month and a half.
Interview Questions: Why the IRC and why this role?

title: Resettlement Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Tallahassee, FL) in Apr 2021
Interview Descriptions: A 30 minute call through Teams. Asked about myself, how did I managed my time, strengths and weaknesses. The interview was good and not hard. I enjoyed it since the person that interviewed me was very nice, that gave me the chance to be relaxed and not stressed about what I was going to be asked about.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself and etc.

title: Youth Career Readiness Coach Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Atlanta, GA) in Apr 2021
Interview Descriptions: I was scheduled to do an interview via Microsoft Teams but the interviewer claimed there was too much feedback (even though I didn't hear any?) so she called me  on the phone instead. She did not begin by telling me who she was, or anything about the position. She just went straight into questions. She also seemed very uninterested and withdrawn from our conversation which was a DEFINITE turn off since she was the recruiter! At that point, I didn't even want the job. But then she asked about my SALARY expectations. I told her, and she proceeded to tell me that the position was hourly and paid significantly less than what I said. Overall it wasn't a good fit but it was easily the worst job interview I have had in a while.
Interview Questions:
Tell me about yourself.
Tell me about a time when you had to work with people you don't get along with. d
Are you fluent in any other languages besides English?

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee in Apr 2021
Interview Descriptions: I let the recruiter know I was on a timeline and she was kind enough to speed up the process and went through several rounds of interviews and submitted 5 references all within 2 weeks. When I asked for a decision, I was told they won't have a decision anytime soon which caught me by surprise considering they sped up the process quickly and made it seem like I would hear back at the end of the week. The interviews were average, standard questions. Bummer, considering I was really passionate about working for the IRC.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself in five years?

title: Immigration Legal Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Elizabeth, NJ) in Apr 2021
Interview Descriptions: Consisted only of behavioral questions. barely lasted 10 minutes. The interviewer had to reschedule and did not have her video on. When I asked her for the next steps, she reluctantly said she would pass my application onto HR. Interviewer overall seemed irritated during the interview. I received an automated email after I sent my thank you letter that they went in another direction.
Interview Questions: Describe a time you asked your supervisor for feedback

title: Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee in Apr 2021
Interview Descriptions: Interview was on Microsoft teams. Interviewer seemed highly disinterested in having the conversation, which was super off putting since she was the HR recruiter! She asked vague questions and seemed perturbed by each of my answers. The interview process was also excessive for a role that paid less than my current nonprofit job at an org of similar prestige - when I asked if there was room to negotiate, she said “no, that’s why it’s a range from 70-75k.” I was told I needed to complete an hour long writing test before advancing to the next round. They also needed five references who could rank my skill set on a scale of 1-10 across various indicators. I withdrew my application after the screen call because I was left with such a negative impression of the org.
Interview Questions: How do you advance gender equity in your work

title: Victims Caseworker Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: The interview was telephonically. It was behavioral based questions. I had the interview in December and didn’t hear back until February telling me they didn’t choose me. I would reach out every often and they kept telling me by the end of the week.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you had to handle confidential information?

title: Communications Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (New York, NY) in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions:
Only received an initial request for an interview over a month after applying, and the amount of time between interview rounds sometimes stretched to 2 weeks. Over the course of 1.5 months I had completed 3 interviews and a writing assessment. All that was left was to see if I got the job. I never heard back.

Got to the final round and was ghosted. And never even heard anything about the writing assessment.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time you centered diversity and inclusion in your work.

title: Housing Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: I was called to schedule about 1 week after submitting resume. I was told by the hiring manager that I will be recommended for the next round. It's expected that it'll  take 2 weeks to get my second interview.
Interview Questions:
Name a time when you had to be direct with someone.
Name a time when you've had to manage multiple  priorities.
How are you working to promote equality.
What makes you want to work for IRC.

title: Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: The process was a long one. The department I applied to was very slow in scheduling and moving the process along.  The person who interviewed me also spent most of the time explaining things that I had already found on the website, meaning the interviews went over the allotted time.
Interview Questions: What experience do you have working with diverse populations?

title: Caseworker Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Nairobi) in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions:
I was contacted on Monday evening about an interview on Wednesday morning. They changed the time twice and I had to wait over an hour on Zoom before they showed up. I was expecting behavioral questions but all I got were general questions about my thoughts on the project and no question specific to the role of Caseworker. 
I waited for three weeks and when I followed up I got the rejection email.
Interview Questions: What are the challenges in sustainability for a Livelihood project?

title: Public Assistances(Remote) Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: Someone from the hiring committee emailed me and sent me a time for the interview. They called me and asked me some basic questions such as why I was interested in the role, my experience working with refugees, and my language proficiency.
Interview Questions:
Why do you want this role?
What are your language proficiencies?

title: Lead Teacher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (New York, NY) in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: Pretty standard. They asked me about how I’ve ensured gender equity in the classroom and how I build relationships. They described the position, what it entailed, and named the salary upfront. I also had to describe my experience working with immigrants and refugees.
Interview Questions: How have you ensured gender equity in your classroom?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Sacramento, CA) in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: There were 2 rounds of remote video interviews after I submitted an online application. All the questions were straightforward questions. The supervisors were kind and understanding. Very easy entry-level questions.
Interview Questions: Do you have any questions for us?

title: Senior Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (New York, NY) in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions:
Contacted about a month after I applied asking for a phone interview. Next was a virtual interview with a more senior department staff, then with the director. The whole process moved quickly but the HR recruiter was very nice and responsive during it. Each interview was short and to the point but conversational, I always felt comfortable. 

Afterwards, I had to submit 5 references and was offered a different role than the one I interviewed for just a day or two after.
Interview Questions:
Why the IRC?
What type of management style works for you?
Tell me about a time things went wrong and how you fixed it.

title: Communications Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (New York, NY) in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: I had a phone interview as a first-round and the phone call was for 30 minutes. It was in general very friendly and easy process but I did not get the second interview.
Interview Questions: What is your strength in remote working?

title: Cultural Orientation Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: Someone from Human Recourses emailed me just a few days after I submitted an application and scheduled a phone interview. The "interview" only lasted about 10 minutes, and the interviewer didn't seem very invested in the conversation, and felt like she was obligated to read a set list of questions. It was a bit uncomfortable.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work here?

title: Data Entry Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: Initial phone interview with HR recruiter, video interview with two team members, excel test, final video interview with manager, asked to provide five references and then I received my offer
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself in 5 years?

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: Very supportive team members interviewed me, very conversational and clear. The staff were accommodating and warm. Some rounds of questions were more intentional and role-focused than others. I felt comfortable asking questions about the work culture, realities of the role, and team cohesion.
Interview Questions:
Experience in the field.
Weaknesses/strengths. 
How do you manage up?

title: Summer Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: Conversational! About half the time she asked me questions and the other half she talked about the internship. She really explains what’s it’s like and warns you a little about what they do so you can think about the position and whether you can take it on.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself.

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: Basic phone call asking about qualifications, goals, and experience. The interview is with your (potential) future supervisor not with Human Resources and you can ask them questions at the end
Interview Questions: How does IRC fit with your career goals?

title: Program Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (New York, NY) in Feb 2021
Interview Descriptions: The first call was a screening call with HR. In addition to behavioral questions, the HR rep asked about salary requirements, start date, etc. The next round was with two direct supervisors for the position. The questions focused on direct experience related to the role with some hypotheticals (i.e. How would you go about conducting M&E for X program). It's good to be familiar with program evaluation language, common indicators, etc. There were also more general questions. Overall, it was a nice environment with friendly and chatty interviewers.
Interview Questions:
General: Why IRC? What book/film has most affected your desire to work in this sector? What is a refugee?

Specific: How would you evaluate  if X program was successful? How would you improve Y program?

title: Investigator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: The interview process is rather standard for this type of role. After submitting an application, I was contacted to arrange a time to speak with a recruiter about my experience and about the position. Following that brief interview with the recruiter, I was contacted to schedule a time to do a written exercise.  After a period of time, I was then contacted for an interview. The interview was with the person who would be my supervisor and with another staff member.
Interview Questions: Are you willing to travel?

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: Two different interviews, initially with a recruiter, and then the program team. Apparently a third interview as well, but I didn't make it that far. The process is incredibly from initial application to each consecutive interview.
Interview Questions:
Describe your understanding of the position you applied for.
What does *program focus area* mean to you?
What experience do you have working with diverse populations?
How will gender affect your work and workplace interactions?

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (New York, NY)
Interview Descriptions: I was invited to a phone interview a few weeks after submitting my application. The interview went well, a few weeks after I reached out to ask about the status of my application, I got no response.
Interview Questions: Describe a past experience where you have navigated a multicultural environment

title: Youth Coach Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: The interviewer was easy to communicate with and set up an interview. The first interview was by phone, and the second interview was a video. She made it clear what they were looking for.
Interview Questions: Do you have a car and are you willing to drive to multiple locations and schools around the area?

title: Workforce Development Specialist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions: The organization does amazing work and  the interviewers were very enthusiastic to learn more and were kind. I wish I get the job. They asked some really great questions. They look for an overall fit in the role and how do you let your passion for carry the day-day tasks of work
Interview Questions: Describe a team when you demonstrated leadership skills

title: Case Worker Interview

Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (New York, NY) in Feb 2020
Interview Descriptions: Difficult, but in an arbitrarily rigid and demanding way. I had multiple rounds of interviews following my phone screen with HR, and the reference stage requires five references (well above the standard three, with two required to be current or former managers) all of whom receive an email survey to complete rather a phone call, which requires its own hand-holding and scheduling. I persevered and corralled five glowing references and ushered them through the survey process, making sure they saw and responded to the email survey within IRC's strict window. It wasn't easy and the HR person was very pushy and unhelpful. The references went in, they were glowing, and after all that I didn't get an offer. I was disappointed because in addition to five references I completed two exercises on top of 4 rounds of interviews with multiple staffers, the second of which was a 90 minute timed exercise. The "exercise" amounted to free work, basically drafting campaign briefs in response to very open-ended prompts, some of which I can see even made it into their marketing materials (so I guess my work was good enough to use!). All in all disappointing and not worth the effort. A place that isn't respectful of a candidate's time is unlikely to respect that of their employees.

title: Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee (Dallas, TX) in Oct 2017
Interview Descriptions:

I was warmly introduced to every member of the staff and given detailed information on every aspect of the program and operation. I was encouraged and embraced and felt confident about my chances for the job when we concluded. I was told I would be called back for a second interview within the next week.

Two weeks later I got a cryptic, short email from the recruiter I spoke with originally who informed me that the group opted not to move forward with my candidacy. I discovered on linkedin about a month later that the Executive Director I hired with had been replaced. 

In short, it was a very informative interview. I love the organization and all that they do. But I was a bit disappointed with their follow up/follow through. I understand internal changes may have complicated the process, and perhaps I'm mostly disappointed that I did not get the opportunity to help them out.

title: Program Coordinator (International Position) Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions:
I was contacted months after filing out an online application. The reason for this window is that the  position was posted before funding had been secured.
The process comprised of 3 interviews in this order: 
1. recruiter - general questions about work history, background, and soft skills
2. technical advisor - very technical questions and most the challenging and decisive interview
3. hiring manager - confirmatory interview, general managerial skills, and to assess personality fit with the team and organizational culture

All in all a smooth, and quick process. After my first interview, I was contacted within 2 days and the second interview was scheduled within a week. And my the third interview was also scheduled within a week. Then I haven't heard form them for 2 weeks so I contacted them to inquire about the status if my application. I was told they would get back to me soon. And they did within 4 days or so with an offer.

I knew I did well in my first 2 interviews, but I wasn't sure about my third interview. The hiring manager was "multitasking" during the interview and seemed too distracted. Barely thanked me for the interview when the interview was over, and hung up so quickly I thought the internet connection was lost and without answering my questions. So when I didn't hear from them within a week as I was told by the recruiter, I thought I didn't get the job. It turns out I was their top choice and pretty much they knew they were going to make me an offer after the second interview. The delay in getting back to me after the interview process just demonstrated to me that the recruiter was exaggerating the urgency of this position. Maybe they get extra points for that, I don't know, but beware, they do that a lot.
Interview Questions:
One question I remember "what is the first thing you'd do on the job".

If the position is technical, the technical interview will be the most important of all. Prepare well. The person interviewing you is a highly experienced expert in the technical area and not a recruiter so prepare and speak from your experience. The person I spoke to didn't seem to mind longer and more elaborate answers. They wanted to be convinced that I did this work before so they asked a lot of

title: Senior Manager Interview

 First, I had 3 phone calls with the same HR person. First to discuss my credentials and work background, the basic job description for which I was being considered, and to gauge my interest and commitment. It was essential at this stage that I not only had the basic education/work experience, but that I also demonstrated strong understanding and commitment of the IRC mission and work. Second, we had a call to discuss the benefit package- I was asked my previous salary and what I would expect to be paid. Then was asked to respond to 4 key questions 1) what I anticipated would be difficult about the job 2) an example of a challenge I faced while working in the field (related job) 3) my management style 4) why I am interested in working on GBV issues
The HR person took notes, and then I asked that I respond to 8 questions in written form within 24 hours. This was shared my the coordinator (boss) in the field, who was the next to interview me. This was go more in depth into my management experience of projects in the field, and to answer any questions I had about the job and the evolving situation. The final interview was a technical interview with the GBV advisor at HQ, and involved questions to gauge my understanding of GBV program design and monitoring. 

I want to highlight the the HR people I talked to and the manager in the field were a pleasure to speak with. They were personable, approachable, and made me want to work for the IRC.

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee
Interview Descriptions:
I was contacted by phone about 1-2 months after submitting my application for an initial phone interview/screening. The person I spoke to was not the hiring manager, but someone on the same team who I think would have been horizontal to the position I was interviewing for. She gave me basic details about the job and asked if I had questions -- all the questions she asked me were very soft -- when I could start, and whether or not the salary range would be a problem, etc. Nothing substantive. The position was very in line with my skill set but the pay was significantly lower than what I am currently making in a city with a 30% higher cost of living than where I live/work now. So...no thanks. But I thought it would be good practice to go ahead with the second interview, and I wanted to ask about the possibility for advancing within the company to see if advancement opportunities might be worth the low initial wage. 

The second phone interview was with both the hiring manager and the first person I'd interviewed with. They both seemed very friendly, and interview questions were very basic....career goals, strengths/weaknesses, etc. I asked some questions about their structure, how decisions were made, advancement...I have a good bit of non-profit experience doing very similar work and none of their answers were very satisfactory to me and I that may have showed in my response. Seems like a big out-of-touch non-profit with bad management issues, poor planning/structure, very top-down and slow moving and high turnover. They were nice and enthusiastic, seemed smart and passionate....but that is not enough to make me want to work for that kind of non-profit again. 

Anyway, they told me a specific date that the final interviews would be happening and that they'd call me soon and let me know either way. They never called again. 

I've done a lot of hiring, and I think this is really bad form. I always send rejection letters to everyone, and even if you get so many applicants that you can't do that, I cannot fathom not sending some sort of notice to someone that you interviewed TWICE. Just reaffirmed that this is not a place I'd like to work.
Interview Questions: Not unexpected, but I hate the "tell us about a specific conflict at work and how you resolved it" question. When I ask that question to people I am interviewing, I always ask more generally what your conflict management style is. Some people will give an example, and some will talk about how to structure work/relationships to minimize conflict.  Both can be good answers, but I prefer having the option.

title: Communications Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at International Rescue Committee in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions:
After a phone interview where I rated myself on software skills, I was asked to do a 2-part test -- writing a letter to a donor, and designing a flyer for an event, which took me several hours, as they both required additional factual research to complete. A couple of weeks later, I was asked to come in for a one-hour interview with two people. They asked some very peculiar generic questions, such as "What tools do you need to be successful?", which I didn't feel were relevant. Later, they asked job-specific questions, such as how I designed the flyer, and how I would set up a travelling photo exhibition. I asked them how they managed having exactly as many unpaid interns as paid employees, and they got incredibly defensive, saying their internship program was very competitive, when all I wanted to know was how long the interns were there for, who was responsible for all of them, what kinds of tasks they did, etc. Having dozens of interns implies they rely on them quite a bit for professional work, but must have constant turnover of institutional knowledge.

They said they would make an offer and notify all the candidates later that same week. One week later, I e-mailed. Two weeks later, I left a voicemail. Four weeks later, I finally got a hold of someone else who told me the position had been filled. After all the time I spent on the interview process (esp. as it was only a low-paid, part-time job), I felt this was unprofessional.
Interview Questions: What tools do you need to be successful?
